material.mattext: when a fiery hot nebula in space coalesced under the force of gravity.
from huge meteoroids that had been flying through intergalactic space.
when another star exploded, shooting rocky debris into space.
from a coalescing frigid cloud of dust and gas.
cool, rigid rock that rides on a continuous shell of molten magma.
cool, rigid rock that rides on a plastic mantle layer.
hot, plastic rock supported by a rigid foundation of cool rock.
cool, rigid rock that floats on the Earth’s molten core.
The biggest mass extinction in Earth’s history occurred at the end of the __________ Period.
To be useful, an index fossil is produced by an organism that:
existed for a relatively short time.
existed for a very long time.
The San Andreas Fault zone is an example of a/an:
earthquake zone at a transform plate boundary.
earthquake zone at a subduction plate boundary.
earthquake at a divergent plate boundary.
Alfred Wegener named the northern part of the supercontinent __________ consisting of what is now North America and Eurasia.
mineral grains, organic matter, gas, and oil.
gold, organic matter, gas, and water.
mineral grains, organic matter, oil, and water.
mineral grains, organic matter, gas, and water.
Wind, flowing water, glaciers, and gravity are agents of __________.
A nutrient-poor lake is called a/an __________ lake.
Most of the surface freshwater (in liquid or frozen form) is contained in:
has no water or plant life.
is drained by streams that flow through it to the ocean
not quite like deflating a balloon
The most abundant constituent  (gas) of our atmosphere is __________.
chlorophyll-bearing plants convert carbon dioxide and water to organic sugars and release oxygen.
primitive bacteria convert hydrogen and oxygen into water.
chlorophyll-bearing plants convert oxygen and water to organic sugars and release carbon dioxide.
primitive bacteria obtain energy from reactions with minerals.
When warm air is heated by the Sun and rises at the equator, it:
is deflected by the Coriolis effect and sinks at the equator in the evening.
splits, travels poleward, is deflected by the Coriolis effect, and sinks at 30° north and south latitudes.
splits and travels poleward, moving due north and south.
travels at high elevation, is deflected by the Coriolis effect, and sinks at the poles.
between the trade winds and the westerlies and is always at the same location.
along the polar front and is always at the same location.
along the polar front and moves with the seasons.
between the trade winds and the westerlies and moves with the seasons.
The biosphere consists solely of the thin zone on the surface of the continents that is inhabited by life.
Many scientists believe that a giant meteorite impact caused the extinction of the dinosaurs.
Where two tectonic plates move past one another, rock near the plate boundary can stretch or compress elastically for decades, and then fracture suddenly and create an earthquake.
Erosion involves little or no movement of the decomposed rocks and minerals.
Fresh water access is easily available all over the world.
Its one of the largest problems the world faces
Many of the world’s largest deserts lie at about 30° north and south of the equator.
As early organisms evolved and multiplied, they depleted oxygen from the atmosphere.
They made more of the oxygen, they didn't deplete it
When geologists study the climate of a region over time, they must separate the effects of tectonic movement from global climate change.
Through the course we learned about various book topics through film clips. What was your favorite film and why? (at least 2 sentences)
What was the most interesting thing you learned in the course through the discussion portion and why?

The final assignment highlighted a more political aspect of climate change and the environment, would you ever choose to become more involved politically for the environment? Or would you prefer to become involved on a less political aspect? Give an example of how you or anyone could get involved for the earth.
